summaries.body: Wilco has put out a free, surprise album, its first in almost three years. It can be downloaded from its website.
Federal prosecutors in Brazil said they were investigating claims of influence peddling by Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, a former president.
One of Google's self-driving cars was involved in an accident that resulted in an injury for the first time. It was rear-ended while stopped at an intersection, the company said.
Planned Parenthood's president apologized for the "tone and statements" of a senior staff member who was secretly recorded in a video that has prompted an inquiry.
Gov. Jerry Brown of California signed into law a bill that blocks adults accused of sexual assault in civil suits from using the defense that the child consented.

display_asset.caption: A young polar bear in the Arctic Ocean in 2009. A multiyear study found that polar bears do not enter a state of what is known as walking hibernation in summer months, when food is more scarce.

summaries.body: Scientists have long considered the possibility that polar bears enter a kind of walking hibernation in the summer, but a new study found no evidence of such a change.
Ellen Pao, who resigned as the head of Reddit, said balancing free speech online with privacy and protection of participants is getting harder. "The trolls are winning," she wrote.
The Conservative government in Britain has set its sights on remaking the BBC, the publicly financed broadcaster, after complaints of a left-wing bias in news coverage.

posts.footer: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, criticizing Donald J. Trump’s border security comments.

summaries.body: What Mr. Trump is offering is not conservatism, it is Trump-ism – a toxic mix of demagoguery and nonsense.
National Journal, a weekly political news magazine, will suspend its print edition. The magazine has been publishing for 46 years.
Tim Farron will lead the Liberal Democrats after beating Norman Lamb in the contest to replace Nick Clegg, who resigned in May after a devastating general election defeat.

display_asset.caption: Thanks to a viral sex video, Sanlitun Village, a Beijing shopping mall, is now home to China’s most famous Uniqlo.

summaries.body: A sex video shot in a Uniqlo fitting room in Beijing managed to go viral despite China's online censors. Now employees are clamping down on selfies at the store.
A new study that analyzed screams found that all of them share a trait called roughness, which is a measure of how fast the loudness of a sound changes.
Former President George Bush remains in the hospital in fair condition on Thursday after breaking a bone in his neck on Wednesday, a spokesman said.

display_asset.caption: Michelle and Jim Bob Duggar in 2012.

summaries.body: TLC is canceling its reality series “19 Kids and Counting.” A report revealed that one of the stars of the show had been investigated on suspicion of molesting underage girls.
Days after a black woman from suburban Chicago was found dead in a Texas jail cell, her friends and family are contesting police statements that she killed herself.
The son of Robert A. Levinson, 67, a retired F.B.I. agent who vanished in Iran eight years ago, said he hopes his father's case becomes a priority after the nuclear deal.
The actor Brad Pitt asked the chief executive of Costco in a letter to stop selling eggs from caged hens, saying the wholesale store contributes to animal cruelty by doing so.
Citigroup reported that its second-quarter profit rose about 18 percent from the quarter a year ago to $4.65 billion, exceeding Wall Street's expectations.
Neil Young, the singer and musician, has said he will not allow his music to be streamed anymore because of poor sound quality.
The crew of the International Space Station moved into the Soyuz vehicle docked to the station as a precaution because of the close approach of a piece of space debris.

posts.footer: The Telegraph's chief sports writer is covering the British Open. Twitter

summaries.body: Painful. Tiger Woods is already 9 strokes behind Jordan Spieth and it's not even noon on the first day of the Open.
An Egyptian Navy vessel caught fire off the coast of Sinai on Thursday after an exchange of gunfire with militants from the shore, the military said.
Dylann Roof, charged with killing nine at a black South Carolina church, is expected in court Thursday where media are challenging a ban on the release of documents related to the case.
A FIFA official detained in a raid in Switzerland has been extradited to the United States, where officials are conducting an inquiry into corruption in the world of soccer.
The British government will publish on Thursday a report calling for “root and branch reform” of the BBC, including a plan to charge poorer families less for their license fee.
The body of Tenzin Delek Rinpoche, a prominent Tibetan monk who died in a Chinese prison, was cremated against his family's wishes, according to his sister.

posts.footer: The Times's Tehran bureau chief, via Twitter

summaries.body: All gas stations in Tehran halting sales after experiencing "technical problems" blamed on a computer system: long lines and angry customers
French intelligence officers have detained four people, including a former member of the navy, on suspicion of planning a terrorist attack against military targets.
Robert Broadbent, a Cleveland retailer who was key to luring the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame to the city, died at 94. His son said he didn't like rock ("It was not his generation").
Samsung Group executives condemned anti-Semitism in a statement after South Korean publications wrote that Jewish financiers were trying to hurt the conglomerate.
EBay is close to selling its Enterprise warehouse and logistics unit to a consortium for about $900 million, a person with knowledge of the matter said.
Amber Heard, Johnny Depp's wife, was charged with bringing their dogs into Australia illegally earlier this year. Officials had threatened to euthanize the terriers.

display_asset.caption: Former President George H.W. Bush in 2014.

summaries.body: Former President George Bush fell at home and broke a bone in his neck. A spokesman said he was in stable condition but would have to wear a neck brace.
The scene as President Obama's motorcade arrived at his hotel in Oklahoma City tonight. Photo by @dougmillsnyt http://t.co/L7e9TCrOPQ

posts.footer: Angie Drobnic Holan, editor of the fact-checking site PolitiFact, which has reviewed 25 statements by the candidate and rated 20 as "false," "mostly false" or "pants on fire," via The Washington Post

summaries.body: I don’t want to turn the whole site into the Donald Trump channel.
Farmers in drought-stricken Thailand were told to leave water supplies for households and wait for rain. "We have to help people to survive first," the country's leader said.
Two electrical engineers were arrested in Mexico on suspicion of helping to build a radio network for a drug cartel along the United States border.
The authorities shut down Darkode, a hacking forum used as a marketplace for stolen personal data and as a training ground for people intending to target more victims.
A woman died at an Ebola treatment unit in Liberia, the second victim since the World Health Organization declared the country free of of the virus in May.
Netflix added about 3.3 million subscribers in the second quarter, 800,000 more than it had projected, the streaming video company said.

display_asset.caption: Cicely Tyson
display_asset.credit: Cindy Ord/Getty Images for I Have a Dream Foundation

summaries.body: Cicely Tyson, above, and George Lucas are among the six artists in the next class of Kennedy Center honorees.
Boeing Co.’s newest 747 jumbo jetliners face a risk of dangerous vibrations on their wings in limited situations, the Federal Aviation Administration said.
Amazon said its Prime Day sale has been more successful than its Black Friday counterpart, but customers on social media have complained about "lame" offerings.
Saved from the brink of closure, Sweet Briar College said nearly 300 students are scheduled to enroll for the next academic year at the 114-year-old women's college.
Gov. Scott Walker, who recently expressed support for a ban on gay Boy Scout leaders because it “protected children,” said he meant protection from the debate over the ban.
Jurors began deliberating in the trial of James E. Holmes, who is charged with killing 12 people in a Colorado theater in 2012.
Amazon Original Movies, an initiative announced in January, has signed on its first movie: Spike Lee's "Chi-Raq," which focuses on violence in inner-city Chicago.
A child sex offender has been indicted on first-degree felony murder charges in the disappearance in 1975 of two sisters from a suburban Maryland mall, authorities said.

display_asset.caption: F. W. Murnau's grave at a cemetery in Stahnsdorf, Germany.
display_asset.credit: Ralf Hirschberger/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

summaries.body: The skull of the director F. W. Murnau, best known for “Nosferatu,” his 1922 film based on Bram Stoker’s “Dracula,” has been stolen from a cemetery near Berlin.
A teenager who survived a plane crash in Washington State but was unable to free two relatives from the wreckage has left the hospital. Officials were trying to reach the site.
Cuba's parliament is holding one of its twice-annual regular sessions with a new twist: It's live-tweeting the proceedings for the first time.
New Jersey weekend drivers had unexpected traffic when a small plane narrowly missed cars as it made an emergency landing on a highway.
Arthur Cave, the 15-year old son of the musician Nick Cave, has died after falling from a cliff in Sussex, England, the family and the police said.
A man attacked an off-duty New York City police officer in the Bronx, punching her in the face and stealing her department-issued handgun, the police said.

display_asset.caption: Plagued for years by soaring litigation costs related to its mortgage problems, Bank of America reported a broad decline in expenses.

summaries.body: Bank of America, seeking to move on from legal and mortgage woes and get on with the banking business, said quarterly profit more than doubled from a year ago.
Two missiles detached from a Tornado jet as it was landing at a British base on Cyprus, a spokesman said. They did not detonate and there were no injuries.
BREAKING: Solar plane attempting around-world flight suspends trip in Hawaii because of battery damage: http://t.co/sC0BDiKteI

display_asset.caption: A Filipino businessman, Mel Velarde, pointing to a replica of a 1734 map he bought at auction in London that shows Scarborough Shoal as part of Philippine territory under Spanish rule. The Philippine government requested copies of historical maps for its arbitration case against China in The Hague.

summaries.body: Google Maps changed the name of a disputed South China Sea shoal after complaints were raised that it was implying the shoal was Chinese territory.
President Hassan Rouhani of Iran told cabinet ministers the nuclear deal was a political victory for the country and it meant Tehran would no longer be regarded as a threat.
The U.S. handed back to Iraq antiquities it said its forces seized in a raid on ISIS fighters in Syria, saying it proved the militants were funding their efforts by smuggling relics.
Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former I.M.F. chief who is hoping to make a comeback, is now living in Morocco and is due to serve as an adviser to the Cuban government.
A judge reduced by $2 million the verdict against Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams over "Blurred Lines," but Marvin Gaye's family will get half of future royalties from the song.
Bills that would lift some restrictions on Japan's military activity overseas were passed by a Parliament committee, amid outrage from opposition lawmakers.

display_asset.caption: Joan Sebastian performing at the Latin Grammy Awards in Las Vegas in 2012. He received a diagnosis of bone cancer in 1999.

summaries.body: Joan Sebastian, a Grammy-winning Mexican balladeer who sang and played guitar while performing equestrian feats, died at 64, in the same rural village where he was born.

display_asset.credit: Gardena Police Department, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A federal judge ordered the Los Angeles suburb of Gardena to release video of the police fatally shooting an unarmed man two years ago.
Prosecutors dropped child sexual assault charges against the brother of Rachel Dolezal, the former N.A.A.C.P. chapter head criticized for identifying as a black woman.
The U.N. AIDS agency said the goal of putting 15 million people on antiretroviral treatment by 2015 had been met, nine months ahead of schedule.
China reported economic growth of 7 percent in the second quarter, slightly more than economists expected.
Twenty foreigners, most of them British and South African, have been detained in northern China for reasons that are unclear, an aid group and the British Foreign Office said.
President Obama called for a bipartisan effort to fix what he called "a broken system" of criminal justice that incarcerates too many Americans for too long.
Scientists at the Large Hadron Collider announced the discovery of a new particle, predicted to exist in the 1960s, called the pentaquark.
Missouri executed David Zink, who was convicted for the 2001 abduction, sexual assault and murder of a teenage girl.
The A.C.L.U. asked a federal appeals court to partly shut down the N.S.A. program that collects Americans’ phone records in bulk, which resumed last month after a lapse.

display_asset.caption: Rob Manfred, the M.L.B. commissioner, at a game last month in San Francisco. On Tuesday, he said M.L.B. had a list of cities it thought were "viable" sites for expansion teams.

summaries.body: Rob Manfred, the Major League Baseball commissioner, said he is open to adding new teams. With 30 franchises, the league has not expanded since 1998.
Planned Parenthood said a secretly recorded video uploaded online falsely portrayed its participation in the sale of tissue and body parts from aborted fetuses.
Aaron Kromer, the offensive line coach for the Buffalo Bills, was placed on indefinite paid leave after he was accused of punching and threatening a boy.

display_asset.caption: Leland and Sharon Bowman were on a plane that took off on Saturday afternoon from Kalispell, Mont., but never arrived at its destination in Lynden, Wash.

summaries.body: After a plane crashed in Washington State, a 16-year-old passenger tried to pull her stepgrandparents out of the wreckage before leaving to get help, an official said.
A federal judge ordered the release of a video showing the police in a Los Angeles suburb fatally shooting an unarmed man in 2013.
Dale Cox, the acting district attorney in Caddo Parrish, La., said he will not run for election in the fall after comments he made on the death penalty stirred controversy.
President Obama spoke at the N.A.A.C.P.'s annual national convention in Philadelphia.
The U.S. expressed concern about Bahrain's treatment of opposition figures after a Sunni leader was arrested and accused of plotting to overthrow the monarchy.
Wal-Mart Stores was accused of discrimination in a lawsuit filed in Boston federal court by an employee who said the company failed to extend health insurance to her wife.
A report attributed to Bloomberg News saying that Twitter Inc. received an offer to be acquired for $31 billion was fake, a spokesman said. Twitter shares rose on the report.
Attorneys are giving their closing arguments on Tuesday in the trial of James E. Holmes, who is charged with killing 12 people in a Colorado theater in 2012.

display_asset.caption: France celebrated Bastille Day on Tuesday with President François Hollande, and Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto, watching a parade of military hardware.
display_asset.title: Scenes of France’s Bastille Day Parade

summaries.body: Fresh from striking a blow for Europe, by mediating the tussle between Greece and Germany over debt, France feted France in its national Bastille Day parade.
Wells Fargo said second-quarter profit fell to $5.72 billion from $5.73 billion a year earlier. On an earnings per share basis, the bank’s profits rose to $1.03 up from $1.01.
Black children were almost four times as likely as white children to be living in poverty in 2013, possibly because of a higher unemployment rate for African-Americans.
Apple introduced mobile payments in Britain, making it available in 250,000 sites in a plan that will eventually be supported by all major British banks.
The U.N. said at least 142 civilians had been killed in Yemen over the past 10 days, bringing the total killed in airstrikes and ground fighting since March 26 to 1,670.

display_asset.caption: Jamie Dimon is chief of JPMorgan Chase, whose overall performance rose in the first quarter.

summaries.body: JPMorgan Chase reported second-quarter earnings of $1.54 a share, compared with $1.46 a year earlier. Follow the news here all week as the largest banks report their results.

display_asset.caption: Curtis Jackson, also known as 50 Cent, pictured on the roof of the G-Unit office near Times Square earlier this year, was ordered last week to pay $5 million over the release of a sex tape.
display_asset.credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times

summaries.body: The rapper 50 Cent called his bankruptcy filing on Monday a "strategic business move" that would allow him to keep working on his music while reorganizing his finances.
At least 27 people died in a stampede at a religious festival in southern India, officials said.
Bicycle lanes have been introduced on some streets in Pyongyang, North Korea's capital, where car ownership is still rare but two-wheeled transportation less so.

posts.footer: A Times correspondent in Monroeville, Ala., Harper Lee's hometown, where the author's new novel "Go Set a Watchman" was released at midnight, via Twitter

summaries.body: Writing thank you notes to #harperlee at the #monroeville bookstore. http://t.co/cGtkeSdETW

posts.footer: From an anonymous note left at an Israeli museum with two sling stones, which the writer claimed to have taken from the ancient site of Gamla, via Haaretz

summaries.body: I stole them in July 1995 and since then they have brought me nothing but trouble.
Laura Poitras, who won an Oscar for her film about Edward J. Snowden, “Citizenfour,” sued several U.S. agencies, saying that airport security officials harassed her for years.
South Korea said two North Korean fishermen who drifted into its waters had been sent home. Three others who asked to defect remained, despite Pyongyang's protests.
Three knife-wielding "terrorists" from the western region of Xinjiang who attacked police officers in a northeastern Chinese city were shot and killed, state media reported.
An Australian editor and his Thai colleague went on trial in Thailand, charged with defaming the navy in an article on human trafficking. They could face seven years in prison.
